title: Cisco Unified Communications Critical Zero-Day Under Active Exploitation (CISA KEV)
affected_products: Cisco Unified CM Session Management Edition (SME)
Cisco Unified CM IM & Presence Service
Unified CM versions 12.5, 14.x, and 15.x prior to patches

timeline.event: Cisco releases emergency patch for CVE-2026-20045, confirms active exploitation
CISA adds CVE-2026-20045 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
SOC Prime reports proof-of-concept exploit code circulating on underground forums
Multiple security advisories issued by CIS, Belgium CCB, and other national CERTs
Continued active scanning and exploitation attempts observed globally

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2026-20045) in Cisco Unified Communications products is being actively exploited in the wild. The flaw allows unauthenticated remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected systems and escalate to root privileges. Cisco confirmed exploitation before patches were available, and proof-of-concept exploit code is now circulating on underground forums.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Organizations using Cisco Unified Communications Manager (Unified CM), IM & Presence Service, Unity Connection, or Webex Calling Dedicated Instance are at risk. This includes enterprises relying on Cisco for VoIP, video conferencing, and unified communications. Millions of organizations worldwide use these products, with unpatched versions 12.5 and 14.x facing the highest risk.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Identify internet-exposed Cisco UC web management interfaces. Step 2: Send specially crafted HTTP requests exploiting improper input validation. Step 3: Gain user-level access to the underlying operating system. Step 4: Escalate privileges to root for complete system control. Step 5: Establish persistence and potentially pivot to other internal systems. Step 6: Access sensitive communications data, voicemails, call records, or use the compromised system for further attacks.
what_you_should_do: Immediately apply Cisco patches - upgrade to Unified CM 14SU3, 15SU5, or later fixed versions
Isolate UC management interfaces behind firewalls if patching is delayed
Monitor logs for suspicious HTTP requests to web management interfaces
Check for unauthorized access or configuration changes on UC servers
Review network segmentation to limit exposure of communication infrastructure
Enable enhanced logging and forward to SIEM for analysis
Block external access to UC management ports if not required
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Cisco Unified Communications products are deployed in millions of enterprises globally, including critical infrastructure, healthcare, financial services, and government agencies. Successful exploitation grants attackers root access to communication systems, enabling interception of calls, access to voicemails, and lateral movement into corporate networks. With POC exploits circulating and active exploitation confirmed, unpatched organizations are at immediate risk. CISA has mandated federal agencies patch by February 11, 2026.

tactics.description: Exploiting the vulnerable web management interface exposed to the network
Executing arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system
Escalating from user-level to root access on the UC server
Creating backdoor accounts for persistent access to communication systems
Accessing voicemails, call recordings, and communication metadata
Using compromised UC infrastructure to pivot to other internal systems

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for unusual HTTP requests to Cisco UC web management interfaces, unexpected privilege escalations, and unauthorized configuration changes. Focus on detecting exploitation attempts through web application logs and system-level process monitoring.

log_sources.description: Web management interface access logs and authentication events
Operating system logs showing process creation and privilege escalation
HTTP/HTTPS traffic to UC management ports (typically 443, 8443)
Correlation of multiple suspicious events targeting UC infrastructure

what_to_look_for.description: Unusual or malformed HTTP requests to web management interface
what_to_look_for.log_field: HTTP request patterns with unexpected input in parameters

what_to_look_for.description: New processes spawned by web server or UC application processes
what_to_look_for.log_field: Process creation events with unusual parent-child relationships

what_to_look_for.description: User-level processes gaining root privileges unexpectedly
what_to_look_for.log_field: Sudo/su events or setuid executions from web context

what_to_look_for.description: Unauthorized modifications to UC system configurations
what_to_look_for.log_field: Configuration audit logs showing unexpected changes

what_to_look_for.description: Outbound connections to unknown external IPs from UC infrastructure
what_to_look_for.log_field: Network flow data showing unusual egress traffic

immediate_actions.description: Inventory all Cisco Unified Communications products and their versions
Upgrade to fixed versions: Unified CM 14SU3, 15SU5, or apply available patch files
Block external access to UC web management interfaces immediately
Ensure comprehensive logging is enabled on all UC systems
Deploy detection rules for CVE-2026-20045 exploitation attempts
Audit web management interface access logs for the past 30 days for suspicious activity
